g:descriptionGroup.p:description: Changes to applications, technology and information environments are implemented in a timely manner, and in response to business needs. Changes, especially their definition, design, development, testing, and deployment, are processed using the standard Change Management process, to ensure their appropriate control and quality of results.

a:principleArtifact.p:rationale: As the business environment changes over time, the information environment (applications, technology, supporting processes etc.) must respond to its changing needs. There should be a formalized and standardized mechanism - Change Management process - enabling an effective and efficient responsiveness to these needs and their transformation into desirable changes. The responsiveness of the Change Management process is crucial. Its bureaucracy, complexity, or poor performance must not block a deployment of necessary changes satisfying business needs to information environment.
a:principleArtifact.p:implications: Change Management process needs to be designed, developed and operated without impractical complexity and bureaucracy, causing unwanted delays of changes. As the changes modify the environment, the architecture needs to be updated accordingly. Using the same Change Management process. To keep a sustainable overview on information environment evolution, all changes need to be documented and recorded in defined data store. If not yet in place, the Change Management process, process staff, and supporting tools will have to be acquired, which can require additional resources. To ensure an appropriate effectiveness and efficiency while managing the changes, all users need to be trained; not only Change Management process staff or IT specialists, but also all users eligible to raise a request for change.
